snippet: Officials in Greece said that despite the latest bailout, the government faces a shortfall of 1.7 billion euros because tax revenue and other sources of income are rapidly disappearing.
abstract: Greek officials say that despite their latest bailout of 130 billion euros they face a shortfall of 1.7 billion euros because tax revenue and other sources of potential income are drying up, and government coffers could be empty as soon as July; Greece's troubles underscore the harsh reality of the way in which prolonged austerity in troubled euro zone economies is making it harder for governments to become self-reliant again.

byline.contributor: Niki Kitsantonis contributed reporting from Athens and Paul Geitner from Brussels.

lead_paragraph: Officials in Greece said that despite the latest bailout, the government faces a shortfall of 1.7 billion euros because tax revenue and other sources of income are rapidly disappearing.

headline.seo: Greece Warns of Going Broke as Taxes Dry Up
